answers.answer: Dear mrc:  Calcifications appear normally in breast tissue.  However, sometimes calcifications will "cluster" around areas of concern.  In this case, a biopsy is needed to determine if there is a cancer "hiding" amongst the calcifications.  IF this is a cancer, then treatment will depend upon her general health as well as the particulars of the tumor.  Surgery is usually recommended and can be breast conserving (lumpectomy + radiation) or mastectomy.  In other words, the treatment is the same as with other age groups but the preferences in an older person may be different.  Additional treatment will, again, depend upon the extent of disease.  The use of hormone therapy will depend upon whether her tumor is estrogen/progesterone receptor positive as well as her ability to tolerate the medication.  Physicians are generally cautious about recommending chemotherapy in older folks....but I think we are crossing a bridge too soon in the  process.  Better to sort out what this is first.

question: My 81 y.o. aunt recently had an abnormal mammogram that revealed "calcification."  She is not clear as to whether that implies blood  vessel or milk duct calcification. She has had no pregnancies. She was a smoker, but has not smoked in 25 years.  History of high blood pressure, recent diagnosis of Parkinson's.  No diabetes. Two of her sisters had breast cancer in their forties (one survived) and another in her 80's who died of other causes.  She is scheduled for biopsy, I assume needle biopsy. (I have not been able to speak with her physician yet.)  My question is, how likely is this to be cancer, and if so, what is the treatment for a woman at her age?  Many thanks...
title: Breast Cancer in Elderly
